channel.title: Using Invisibles To Opt Out of Functions In a Chain
channel.description:
[One idea for using invisibles](https://rebol.metaeducation.com/t/making-invisible-functions-e-g-comment-elide/2034) is to chain functions where you make some functions disappear from the chain if they're not needed.
Imagine an image processor where you apply sequential effects but only the ones specify as refinements.
imagemagick: func [ data :monochrome :sharpen :blur :pixelise ][ ... code .. sharpen: either sharpen [sharpenf/] [ghost/] blur: either blur [blurf/] [ghost/] pixelise: either pixelize [pixelf/] [ghost/]
return sharpen blur pixelise data ]
imagemagick/sharpen imagedata
The GHOST function vanishes, giving a much cleaner look. If the refinements are absent, the functions just disappear.

item.dc:creator: hostilefork
item.description:
gchiu:
sharpen: either sharpen [sharpenf/] [ghost/]
blur: either blur [blurf/] [ghost/]
pixelise: either pixelize [pixelf/] [ghost/]

return sharpen blur pixelise data

This kind of application no longer works, as it was a casualty of scaling back what "invisibility" could do.

"Non-Interstitial Invisibility" was removed for good reasons that are outlined here:

Making Invisible Functions (e.g. COMMENT, ELIDE)

So to have invisibles vaporize anything, you'd need to go through a COMPOSE or REDUCE step and then EVAL the result... so not that succinct. CHAIN is a better bet here.

Though at time of writing, you can get the original intent with macros:

sharpen: macro [] [return if sharpen [sharpenf]]
blur: macro [] [return if blur [blurf]]
pixelise: macro [] [return if pizelize [pixelf]]

return sharpen blur pixelise data

item.title: Using Invisibles To Opt Out of Functions In a Chain
item.dc:creator: hostilefork
item.description:
gchiu:

One idea for using invisibles is to chain functions where you make some functions disappear from the chain if they're not needed.

This is a creative idea... and I think this sort of creativity is what makes the language fun...

In this particular case, you could actually use CHAIN to build the composite function, and it might be more obvious:

imagemagick: func [
    data 
    :monochrome
    :sharpen
    :blur
    :pixelise
][
     ... code ..
    return run chain reduce [
        ? if sharpen [sharpenf/]
        ? if blur [blurf/]
        ? if pixelize [pixelf/]
    ] data
]
